author: {'steamid': '76561198044785009', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 466, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 466, 'last_played': 1711061123}
review:
So for context, I put this game on my wishlist back in 2015. I saw the steam sale one day and went, will I buy this finally or remove this out of respect for the developer?
And honestly, it came for me at the perfect time in my gaming life, as I was coming off a bad experience with another game. In terms of "flaws" the art in this isn't high grade, and there's some minor age issues I'd warn ahead of time (you will need to go and change the resolution in a txt file manually if you use a 4k resolution monitor or television; then you must also change the resolution in-game. controller may require toggling steam input) 
But overall I like it. its a roguelike game that you can easily lose 30 minutes-2hours in a run with its charming subplot humor that plays well with controllers. Even when you try to spend extra time using the avoidable side quests for cash/exp/gear, you will always be at risk if an enemy boss stats are high enough (enemies have a potential to crit just as much as you are) so you're never truly safe. And with variable difficulty, with the dungeons also getting progressively harder, the casual player can enjoy themselves just as much as the hard nosed roguelike lover. Usually in this kind of game, its either mostly easy, or way too hard, so it tells you the devs actually put some thought into this. And a certain character making an appearance from another game, for those who know, genuinely caught me off guard and made me excited! So kudos for that collab.
Good purchase, one that if you're looking for a low end spec time waster you'll find many far worse then this especially at its price point. I think if you're looking to get into the roguelike genre, this may be a more gentler introduction then most to see if you would like to try this genre or not.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063465895', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 462, 'playtime_forever': 1267, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1267, 'last_played': 1707622302}
review: For both it's cost and it's charm, I'd say this was worth the investment. The game can be a little unfair and has some balance issues - namely with bosses just dodging everything and one-shotting you, and the same goes for quest NPC's - but there's a heart to this game that I find gives me a smile when I think about it. It's not the most complex or detailed roguelike, but as the project of a single person? I'd say it was a very good effort indeed. Give it a go, you'll probably have some fun with it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075868257', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 105, 'playtime_forever': 1169, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1169, 'last_played': 1701558861}
review:
I feel a little bit mean giving this a thumbs down because I do enjoy playing it from time to time.

It's got a nice simplicity about it and it's good for killing a few minutes when you have nothing else to do.

But the big reason I can't recommend it is because the game trains you to just keep spamming your most basic attack on every enemy you come across, and then when you encounter a boss you end up attacking it too quickly and not noticing you've been losing huge chunks of your health and need to use a recovery item.

There are so many ways that could be mitigated - some kind of warning noise when your health gets too low, purposely slowing the player's actions down when facing a much tougher enemy, having an auto-heal feature.

Or even if the rest of the gameplay had more substance than 'charge through everything and occasionally manage your inventory or visit a merchant' it might help to avoid training the player to just spam attack everything.

(Note that the way you interact with loot-containing obstacles on the map is also to just charge into them, the same way you attack things.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198056629216', 'num_games_owned': 856, 'num_reviews': 124, 'playtime_forever': 136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 136, 'last_played': 1672257082}
review:
This game has been done before and better tbh.  If you've never played Fatal labyrinth (the og imo), pixel dungeon or the enchanted cave, than you may enjoy this game.  However, if you've played the above games previously you'll quickly realize this game runs out of juice by the 4th floor and there are 10 floors to complete.  Bosses are completely unbalanced if you get hit by one they can easily one shot you, progression is grindy and as I said before once you get to the 5th floor you're practically begging to stop playing the game.  

In short, it's not a bad game if this is the only one you know about, however there are better options out there.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971838196', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 356, 'playtime_forever': 529, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 529, 'last_played': 1658764517}
review:
Spielwertung: 6/10
Spielzeit: ca. 9 Stunden
Spieldurchläufe (2 beendet, erste 2 Karten, 3. Karte Endbosse)

Simpel, durchaus anfixend, aber leider furchtbar unbalanced und 0 geeignet für kleinste Aufmerksamkeitsschwächen

Es gibt ein hervorragendes Review von "Ryutaa", das zumindest bei mir direkt das erste Review auf der Shopseite ist (English). Er/Sie beschreibt im Grunde in aller Ausführlichkeit, warum das Spiel ziemlich sinnlos gebalanced ist. Jeder Mini-Questboss kann der Tod sein. Im Grunde sind alle immer OP, wenn man sie direkt von der Karte säubern will und nicht erst z.B. in Level 3 geht und später zu Level 2 zurückkehrt. Ja, man kann jeden Boss durch diverse Tricks runterschleifen, aber das ist für so ein simples Spiel viel zu komplex. Wie Ryutaa schreibt, sind alle Range-Gegner eine Katastrophe, wenn man selbst nicht in der Lage ist, sie vor dem Angriff zu töten. Andererseits sind die eigenen Range-Heros völlig op im Vergleich zu den Melees. 

Das man nicht mal 1 Extraleben bekommen kann (wäre für diese "kleinen" Abenteuer vielleicht zu viel) ist trotzdem frustrierend. Ja, auch was andere schreiben stimmt: Das Spiel an sich geht, wenn man zügig ist, 30-60 Minuten, danach ist man "fertig". Man kann die Runs noch auf 2 "neuen" Karten wiederholen, aber die gehen alle ungefähr gleich lang. Trotzdem: Man stelle sich vor, man spielt langsam, vorsichtig, full clear aller Quests (tolle Idee an sich!) und Gegner und hat sich Equipment/Level aufgebaut, die basically alles oneshooted und dann stirbt man, weil man einmal kurz nicht aufpasst und den Dot nicht sofort bemerkt hat (ist mir im letzten Run auf der 3. Karte passiert...)

Alles, was man tun kann, ist wieder von vorne anzufangen. Dafür gibt das Spiel zu wenig her. Zu wenig Spannung, Inhalt, Belohnung. Konstantes Konzentrationshochhalten, obwohl 99% der Zeit nix relevantes passiert, wenigstens kann man Musik dazu anmachen, da der Sound seine Abwechslung schon nach 10 Minuten verliert. 

Ich habe, um mich mal in das Spiel vorzutesten (ich hatte durchaus vor danach bewusst den Schwierigkeitsgrad zu erhöhen) mit einfach angefangen, also 1/4. Ich habe sofort den Krieger gepickt, weil das normalerweise meine Klasse ist, schön rein in Nahkampf, viel Leben, viel Rüstung, dicke Waffen. Zumindest im klassischen RPG-Auswahlverfahren mit Magier und Schütze. Nun, was soll ich sagen, nach 3 frustrierenden Runs hätte ich das Spiel fast schon wieder deinstalliert. 
Weiter gings mit Mage. Das ist einfacher, aber durch das Mana-Management auch langweilig/anstrengend. 
Weiter zum Ranger/Schützen und, naja, viel leichter gehts wirklich nicht mehr. Die Bosse sind zwar immer noch ein Pain in the A**, aber im Grunde kann den Schützen nix stoppen. Außerdem hat er nicht so viele Skills, also kriegt man meistens schnell Gratisbücher und kann die Fähigkeiten wirklich gut nutzen. Vor allem "Schlaf" hatte stets 100% Erfolgsgarantie, auch bei jedem Boss, das ist völlig op. Aber selbst das hilft nichts (diesmal auf "Normal"), wenn man, wie beschrieben, nur 1 Sekunde nicht aufpasst, wegrennt, den Dot nicht sieht und einfach stirbt...

Ich will nicht wissen, was man auf Schwer und Hell so erlebt. Dafür muss man das Spiel wahrscheinlich sehr, sehr lieben...

Fazit: Das Spiel ist eigentlich grundsolide und macht auch zuweilen Spaß. Viel erwarten darf man natürlich nicht, dafür fehlt wirklich zu viel Umfang, es sind 3 Maps, 5 Helden, jeweils 5 oder 6 Kartenlevel, thats it. Die Daumen hoch / runter wird dem Spiel imo nicht gerecht, aber aufgrund des hohen Frustfaktors - schweren Herzens - Daumen runter.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069065539', 'num_games_owned': 2221, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 241, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 241, 'last_played': 1650908518}
review:
[i]Quest of Dungeons[/i] is a fantasy-themed roguelike. With an incredibly simple design that lacks any draw to pull players in to replay the game, some key missteps in the battle system, and an imbalanced roster of playable characters, this subpar roguelike offers players no reason to purchase it above the more polished competitors in the indie roguelike space. Go try [i]Vampire Survivors[/i] if you want a taste of mobile game-inspired mindless combat done right, or the [i]Rogue Legacy[/i] games for fantasy-themed roguelikes that actually satisfy.

You play as one of four fantasy archetypes: the Warrior, the Wizard, the Assassin, or the Shaman, each with their own attack pattern and abilities to discover. You're tasked with crawling through floors of a dungeon with successively more difficult enemies. Play a game of cat-and-mouse as you try to survive and grow stronger, looting treasure and equipment along the way to enrich and empower yourself. Can you make it to the bottom of the dungeon?

[i]Quest of Dungeons[/i], which to my knowledge began its life as a Steam game, feels like a mobile game in a bad way. The experience presented is an extremely rudimentary roguelike: face randomized assortments of enemies in random map layouts with random item drops. The problem lies not with the randomization but the lack of content to actually be randomized, as every floor looks and feels the same, pretty much every enemy has the same nondescript melee attack, and the treasure hunting/equipment purchasing loop feels unrewarding due to just how little of an impact new weapons and armor have on the gameplay experience. The draw of this really is just exploration and killing enemies, over and over and over again.

Combat in this is a rote affair, too, because of what little info the game shares with players. By far the biggest challenge here is not the final boss nor floor bosses, but random minibosses that can spawn in due to taking quests and that scale way above the player's level. With most enemies being disposable mooks when one plays attentively, you'll never know when one happens to come along with ranged attacks that can one-shot you. Any indication of enemy power level could've helped solve this. Enemies also can't be fled from if they get too close as they perfectly track player movement, and downing healing items takes a turn of combat, meaning there's no way to gauge an enemy's strength and tactically retreat. So combat is just a random guessing game - and it only takes one bad roll of RNG to send your efforts down the drain.

Even the four playable characters are inherently imbalanced. The Assassin (who should've been named The Archer) is far and away the strongest playable character, as they're the only one with a long range basic attack that's not subject to mana costs. This means only one-shot attacks from long range threaten them, while everyone else is forced to trade health for experience points in melee combat, vastly increasing the risk of engaging an unbeatable foe. Even on Easy Mode the imbalance in character design and unspecified threat levels of enemies tarnish the player experience.

[i]Quest of Dungeons[/i] is an undercooked roguelike. Uninspired enemy design, imbalanced character loadouts, and a lack of crucial information provided to the player makes this an annoying and shallow experience. For most players, you'll get to see everything there is to this game from a partial twenty minute playthrough. While some players familiar with the design pitfalls of the cheap mobile game formula may feel at home with this title, I doubt many would be interested in coming back for seconds. [i]Quest of Dungeons[/i] gets a D+.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031261101', 'num_games_owned': 2317, 'num_reviews': 143, 'playtime_forever': 260, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 242, 'last_played': 1646819459}
review:
With the game's elements ranging from mediocre to terrible in terms of quality or depth, this'd be a dubious option even at free.


From controls that lack basic functionality (eg, the ability to use left or right click to move and the other click to attack; Instead, expect very limited mouse controls) to lacking user conveniences like pathing-pausing on monster reveal, to clumsy interaction polish, the game's design is extremely dated, being in some ways worse than games from the 80s and 90s, and certainly comparing poorly to most modern offerings. 

The keyboard only movement is too clunky to favor, and the mouse movement.. well, it's so quirky that my attempts to attack the boss monster simply got me killed before I could even take another action, due to it deciding I should circle around the boss instead of attacking it with my bow. Solid. 

And let's not get into those moments where the game just flat out didn't let me attack at all, for no clear reason whatsoever, and I died to trash mobs for, again, no reason whatsoever. And this happened, well, a lot. Honestly, this may be one of the hardest roguetypes I've ever played, for all the wrong reasons.

So from that, we can determine that the game is significantly lacking in both user appeal and polish. But then there's the gameplay which, well.. I honestly prefer Castle of the Winds (1989), or similarly straightforward flash roguetypes. Even the most basic roguetype options out there, including the three decade old CotW, have better developed loot, {narrative, lore, and/or questing}, combat, and other systems. Ouch. But when you also factor in that so many roguetypes have been presented over the past three decades, especially in more recent years, that've long since pushed past the basic explore+click to attack generic mobs+basic RNG loot dynamic..

Well, to call this "unambitious" is an understatement. Frankly, it's not on par with your basic free flash roguetype, and it's structured in fundamentally the same manner. So why pay $5 for something you can get a better experience on for free? Nevermind all the paid options out there that are legitimately interesting, or traditional offerings that far exceed this game on both controls and gameplay options.



So, rather than being an issue of the game being outright bad.. Well, "extremely low-effort knockoff of Nethack/CotW/etc" would have been a hard sell for recommendation decades back, nevermind these days, where we're comparing roguetype releases against entirely different games. Simply put, it's not something most modern gamers would expect to be paying money for and, if we go past that, it's just not an interesting enough game to hold up against competition even if it were a free offering. And I really want to emphasize that, the game is just profoundly uninteresting. 

Again, it's not only lacking many modern systems of appeal, it's lacking nearly all of the older rogue format game systems as well. It's an extremely barebones offering that really'd only appeal to those who want a barebones tactical RPG without any real unlocks or tactical depth or exploration appeal or questing or, well, anything. And even if you've got such unique tastes, you can still find offerings with better polish on controls. 


Put another way: You see what's listed on the store page description for the game? That's literally all the game has. Don't expect any unlock systems, and combat depth, any interesting dungeon mechanics, or anything else. Just expect the barebones elements listed on the store page. 

In fact, let me cover those real quick:
* Procedural dungeons, 4 difficulty levels, Procedural weapons, Permadeath: Okay, those're all just basic, and none of them are really done especially well despite that.
* Boss encounters: Also standard, and also underdeveloped. Other'n being able to kill you easier, and having different skins, these are pretty uninteresting, and don't earn you anything notable. In standard gaming terms, these'd be more in line with "Elites", rather than mini-bosses or bosses.
* Quests: These are basic "find X monster on your floor and defeat them to get bonus xp and gold" bounty tasks, as per a typical MMO or Final Fantasy side quest. As far as I've seen they only first start appearing on the second floor of a dungeon. Nothing remotely interesting from any of a gameplay, lore, or reward perspective.
* Shops: Uninteresting, just like the loot system on the whole.

And let's not forget that you also get:
Terrible controls, a very glitchy game, poorly polished recognition of input, and buckets of frustration.

Beyond those extremely basic things, there's just nothing else to the game. Rather, you DON'T get these staples of the genre: User-convenience features. A full looting system. Special encounters. Pets. Complex weapons and spells. Complex dungeon layouts. In-game or post-game trait, ability, or feature unlock functionality. Tactical depth. A good time.

As a final note, non-toggleable perma-death is an absolutely terrible inclusion in a game that sabotages your controls. For that reason alone, I'd Not Recommend this game, even if it did have merits- which, again, it sorely does not.

If you absolutely have to play this game, at least do it with the warrior selected. At least you don't generally get screwed over too badly if a melee character spontaneously suicide rushes enemies. Though if that's what you're into, I'd just recommend you get a D&D CRPG and play as a barbarian, with suitable associated roleplay, instead. Or maybe load up an MMO and create a character with a name as close to Leeroy Jenkins as you can manage. Y'know, for reasons.

review: My run ended with a randomly generated monster that appeared in an already visited space that two shotted me. author: {'steamid': '76561198012114785', 'num_games_owned': 517, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 118, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 118, 'last_played': 1641318669}
review:
Dungeon molto ripetitivi, nemici tra loro molto simili e boss inaffrontabili:
- Guerriero: buono per i primi livelli, ma dovendo affrontare tutto in mischia (ossia: avanza contro il nemico e continua a schiantarti addosso fino a che non muore) è totalmente inutile contro un qualunque boss (che per ragioni assurde infliggono una quantità di danni spropositata, tanto da essere inaffrontabili in mischia);
- Mago: tanti danni coi sui incantesimi, ma la rigenerazione del mana è terribile (2 di mana ogni quanto, 20 caselle percorse?? seriamente non esiste alcun oggetto per la rigenerazione del mana, ad eccezione delle pozioni? no equip? il bastone da mago è nulla di più di una spada, non serve ad altro!); pochi incantesimi realmente utili (palla di fuoco iniziale, pioggia di fuoco solo perché saltuariamente incendia e teletrasporto... gli incantesimi di cura sono inutili se consumano la metà del mana totale) 
- Arciere: vedi mago, ma togli il mana e metti un arco che fa la metà dei danni (ma almeno le frecce sono infinite!), non male fino a che il nemico non te lo ritrovi in faccia perché le tue frecce non gli fanno danni..e  quindi sei morto, perchè giustamente i boss fanno una quantità di danni pari alla tua vita massima, il che buol dire che sei sei di fianco a loro sei morto
- Druido: un guerriero... depotenziato? Seriamente, può spaventare i nemici (ossia immobilizzarli per 3 turni) ed evocare un costrutto... che, per il fatto che i nemici attaccano solo te e non il costrutto, è totalmente inutile se non lo usi per bloccare le porte (e poi... cioè, puoi attaccare il tuo costrutto se per errore clicchi nella sua direzione e ti è di fianco??? a che serve??)

In conclusione: sconsigliato, tutti gli equip sono uguali, o quasi (+ difesa per tutti in genere), e i boss in normale ti fanno fuori con un colpo, così a caso (e se ti sono di fianco? non puoi allontanarti da loro se non sei un mago, curarti non ti serve se tanto ti tirano via, se va bene, metà vita massima ad ogni singolo attacco)... in poche parole: sconsigliato

review: Imagine most archaic and empty point and click d&d and you get this game. Main way, implemented by developers, to restore your hp as a melee character is to walk in a circle for a 2 minutes and wait for full hp restore, then go fight with a boss, walk 2 minutes, next room, walk 2 minutes. After one, not even full run, this game is so boring.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015705329', 'num_games_owned': 1671, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 1120, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 943, 'last_played': 1708808173}
review:
[h1]klein aber fein[/h1]

Ein Spiel, so einfach und doch so schwer. Quest of Dungeons ist ein prozedurales Roguelike, dass aussieht (und sich manchmal auch spielt) als ob es schnell im Game Maker zusammengezimmert worden wäre. Quadratische Tiles in Pixeloptik, man springt immer ein Feld weiter, Animationen gib es kaum.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2570362496

Und doch... es hat etwas. So simpel wie es ist, so schwer ist es zu meistern. 
Anfänglich stehen vier Helden zur Auswahl, später fünf, die sich alle in ihren Fähigkeiten und im Kampfstil unterscheiden. Nahkampf, Fernkampf, Magie, gemischt, für jeden ist was dabei.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2570362809

Das Prinzip ist einfach: man läuft durch den Dungeon - quasi rundenbasierend, man bewegt sich ein Feld, dann die Monster - killt Monster, lootet, bringt das Zeug zum Händler, verkauft es und kauft Tränke oder Equipment. Mittels Treppen wechselt man eine Ebene nach oben oder unten. Dazu gibt es ab und an eine Tafel mit Quest (töte xy, finde yz#) oder ein Bossmonster. Soweit so einfach, oder? 
Nein - Zum einen geben Skills und Spells mit Cooldownzeit bzw. Mana dem Spiel etwas taktische Tiefe, Findet man die richtigen Schlüssel (oder kauft sie) bekommt man Zugang zu wichtigem, starken Equipment. Zum anderen verzeiht es keinen Fehler. Da hat man einen schon quasi unbesiegbaren Helden, öffnet eine Türe und trifft den falschen Boss oder das falsche Questmonster, sieht nicht gleich, wie viel Schaden man frisst oder verklickt sich, läuft quer in den Raum und zack- Permadeath, man beginnt wieder von neuem. Neues Level, neue Gegner, man unterschätzt eine Art (Blutungsschaden, Frostschaden) oder ein kritischer Treffer und man verliert mehr Energie als man dachte ... Und in der Tat - die meisten Tode wären vermeidbar, wenn ... ja wenn man die Aufmerksamkeitsspanne hoch halten würde. Doch umso stärker man wird, desto automatischer kämpft man sich durch und übersieht dann eben genau das eine kleine Detail, wegen dem man dann abkratzt. Und das ist der Nervenkitzel daran, den perfekten Run hinzukriegen. Mein erster Sieg dauerte etwas über eine Stunde (Einstieg bis Boss besiegt)- ich hatte zu dem Zeitpunkt aber schon 10h im Spiel verbracht.

Für ein paar Euro ein schnelles Spiel zwischendurch, das oft frustriert, aber hin und wieder gönnt. Mir macht es Spaß und ich geb mir das Spiel immer wieder mal. Vollpreis ist ok, wie etwa ein Mobilegame ohne Ingame Transaktionen. Im Sale macht man nichts falsch.

___________________________________
Ich hoffe meine Rezension hat dir gefallen!
Schau gerne bei unserer Kuratorengruppe vorbei. Ehrliche Reviews von den verschiedensten Leuten.
Wir sind [url=https://steamcommunity.com/groups/Die_Unbeschreiblichen]"Die Unbeschreiblichen"[/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561198079400243', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 740, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 695, 'last_played': 1704525659}
review:
These types of games aren't my typical 'go to' - I have nothing particularly against them, but I just tend to lean more towards simulations. 

That being said, I thoroughly enjoy this game. The maps randomly generate, and as far as I can tell, I haven't ever had the same map twice - which makes it much more enjoyable in itself.

It's a simple game, yet can be challenging. 

Highly recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991043929', 'num_games_owned': 363, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 79, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 79, 'last_played': 1610160672}
review:
I am a fan of Pixel Dungeon and its clones on Android. They have helped me pass time while waiting for an appointment or my wife to finish shopping. I thought Quest of Dungeons might be an equally fun time waster and more complex dungeon crawler to play on my computer. Unfortunately, it just isn't the case. 

Quest of Dungeons is very basic and repetitive. I feel like I am grinding after 10 minutes of play. There is little character, loot, or level progression. Each level is basically the same. The music is repetitive and oddly upbeat for a dungeon crawler. Most traps are visible and are not a threat. The game is too easy for a roguelike. 

I hate to give an indie game a negative review because someone may have put their heart creating this, but the gameplay just doesn't come together in a compelling way for me (despite liking the genre). With the "Mostly Positive" reviews, I really thought I would like Quest of Dungeons. I'd refund the game, but I am well passed the return policy now.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045741611', 'num_games_owned': 89, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 374, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 83, 'last_played': 1626006957}

It doesn't pretend to be anything other than what it is and it's blummin' so good too! An enjoyable romp through RPG land!

author: {'steamid': '76561197976418610', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 232, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 232, 'last_played': 1608874996}
review: Slightly charming, but not enough variety or depth to make it enjoyable. I've only played a few hours and feel that I've seen all the game has to offer. Enemy encounters are extremely repetitive and trivial (at least in easy and normal settings), and it mostly just feels like you're grinding to prepare your character to face the boss, which can put a huge hurting on you even on the easiest difficulties. The only sense of strategy that I felt was in trying to manage and use your spells efficiently.

author: {'steamid': '76561198296579803', 'num_games_owned': 193, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 88, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8, 'last_played': 1614369842}
review: Ok so I have been seeing some bad reviews. If you love retro rpg/roguelikes for 5 dollars even if it is not on sale you get your moneys worth and then some. Amazing game I paid for the ios version as well. You guys need to start judging games based on price and the type of game. If you don't like repetitive gameplay roguelikes are not for you. I love doing simple combat with depth in the gameplay., levels and adventuring. Ignore the negative reviews and buy this especially for 2 dollars.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972499098', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 7, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7, 'last_played': 1607064561}

author: {'steamid': '76561198053201270', 'num_games_owned': 2706, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 3486, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3486, 'last_played': 1607198457}
review:
I realize I spent way too much time completing this game. But I wanted to get all the achievements.
Disregarding that, it is actually a really cool adventure/rogue-like dungeon crawler.
It has 5 unique characters with different builds with 4 different levels you can play them on. 
The game is pretty challenging even on the easier difficulties but still feels rewarding when completing bosses or stages especially with the achievements that are very well implemented.

I do have a few issues with it though. 
The biggest one for me without a doubt is the permanent death, coupled with the useless feature of savegames.
Why have a save feature if you would die permanently anyways? This feature feels overlooked and lazily implemented.

And then there is the problem with character balancing. Some of the characters are literally useless especially on the higher difficulties. The necrodancer for example is awful in most aspects, she has a few good defensive spells but pretty much all her offensive spells are very weak in comparison to the mage. The Assassin class (which is basically an archer build), is way too overpowered compared to the other classes. It has a long range attack without using mana plus it has spells like sleep which can never fail, which is just insane. It can also move much faster in the grid than the other characters which doesn't really makes it more powerful or anything, it just makes it faster to complete a level.

Another thing I noticed is the difference in the difficulty levels. I noticed there is a difference between like Easy and Hell. But I can't really put my finger on what exactly makes Hell more difficult than Easy. Because when i played my Hell playthrough it didn't really feel much differently compared to easy or normal except that I cleared the rooms more subtly. I still got an amazing build with great weapons and armor and stuff. And I easily managed to kill the last boss. It could be the economy system that maybe made it less lucrative to use the merchant or something i'm not sure.

Also a cool thing I noticed when I started playing this game is that it uses the same sprites as the GPS-based RPG game Orna uses. Which I also play and recommend. It's on google play and appstore as well i believe. 

In conclusion a good casual game worth playing, I typically enjoyed playing it while watching a podcast or listening to music.
I think I got this game for free somewhere or in a bundle. So content in comparison to my price 10/10. For 5 bucks, I probably rate it 7/10. I would definitely recommend buying this game during a winter sale or something like that.

review: I found this game years ago on switch. It was one of the first games I bought back when there were only a handful of games on the system. It was a random buy and since has become one of my all time favorite games. The sounds and music along with the simple but challenging game-play have captured many memories. Just hearing the music brings me back to better times and assures me that there may be better times again in the future. Thank you for porting this to so many devices and thank you for this game. It may just be assets and pixel art with basic mechanics but to me it is something special.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025522562', 'num_games_owned': 1499, 'num_reviews': 242, 'playtime_forever': 505, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 505, 'last_played': 1597692742}
review:
I will recommend this game but it's not that good. It's a bit fun crawling around the generated dungeons and it gives you a retro feeling. But there are just a bit to much RNG and you have to get lucky to have a good chance of beating the game. For example, some times you get a lot of tomes that are almost crucial if you want to kill some of the bosses further down the dungeon. But if the RNG is not in your favor you will just be killed. Bosses are usualy placed in a way where you have 5 round before they get close to you and when they do you are just in for a battle of luck unless you have good tomes in stock. Usually your normal attack get dodged andthe boss kills you in 2-3 rounds.
As another example is that I completed the first dungeon on my first try on normal. But I have not been able to complete the second dungeon, even on easy, I've gotten to the last boss once but I was dead in two hits. The game is just not fun if I must turn to RNG luck.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041990871', 'num_games_owned': 882, 'num_reviews': 254, 'playtime_forever': 101, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 101, 'last_played': 1597004663}
review: Really simple dungeon crawler that is easy to pick up and play. That is the best thing going for the game. If you are looking for something innovative and exciting, look somewhere else. If you have a couple minutes to kill and want some basic rouge-like exploration, then this is the game for you. There are enough classes to try out to play for a couple hours. For only a couple dollars it's an alright game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198276773514', 'num_games_owned': 1300, 'num_reviews': 133, 'playtime_forever': 54, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 54, 'last_played': 1593065202}

author: {'steamid': '76561198045777447', 'num_games_owned': 1151, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 541, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 460, 'last_played': 1673870844}
review:
Absolutely great game, that I own on Android and Switch as well as Steam, and it's on my Itch wishlist to get a DRM-Free version for PC to have an "archival" copy of it.

Very "retro" game, but highly playable, with a fairly modern interface and controls that make it simple to learn rather than using esoteric commands like many similar titles do.

Also, when they say "roguelike" here, they actually mean it. This is an actual roguelike, not a rogue-lite, game. For traditionalists such as myself this is a major plus. While I do enjoy quite a few rogue-lites, having them listed as a roguelike bothers me, but this actually meets the standard of being a true roguelike game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198837947230', 'num_games_owned': 353, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 250, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 233, 'last_played': 1594112181}

author: {'steamid': '76561198103420866', 'num_games_owned': 473, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 2485, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2485, 'last_played': 1592033011}
review:
This game is a great roguelike dungeon crawler to play while watching videos/TV shows/etc. I enjoyed the focus on simplicity, as you can have a relaxed gameplay experience, where moments are introduced that require you to decide how to deal with each room's enemy layout.

Two issues I had with the game were certain quests you would recieve, and aspects of the final bosses.
There was a drastic difference between them and the typical enemies you encounter, given that they have the potential to kill you in two turns. When I ran into these moments, I did feel cheated, but that's what comes with permadeath games. 

It is entirely possible that I just feel this way because I often fall into auto-pilot mode, where I move the character as if it was a real-time game, instead of move tile-by-tile and plan my actions. (If you are willing to adopt some unusual tactics, you can make it through. You decide. *shrug*)

Nevertheless, it's a fun romp, so its worth taking a look at.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018090675', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 435, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 435, 'last_played': 1504264811}
review:
Extremely shallow roguelike that falls down in all key areas - it lacks meaningful procedural generation, meaningful choices, emergent gameplay, a satisfying growth in power or challenge, interesting quests or goals, and an interesting combat system. It's basically the roguelike you build as a tutorial to learn a new language, complete with generic assets.

If you would like to play a cartoony, fun, lunchbreak roguelike capable of being replayed, then I would recommend One Way Heroics instead. Almost any roguelike would really be a better option though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039351953', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 902, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 363, 'last_played': 1636143413}
review:
Quest of Dungeons is a fun game of dungeon crawling with heroes and their unique powers. Because the dungeons are randomly generated every run is different. 
This could be one of those smaller games that you keep on your pc just to play to fill 30mins or so.

Pro's:
- Nice art
- Turn based 
- "Just one more run" syndrome 
- Unlockables! 

Con:
- Controls sometimes lock-up (Solved with a reboot)

Nitpick:
- The jokes feel out of place.
(Got my copy from Humble bundle)

author: {'steamid': '76561198107888561', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 116, 'playtime_forever': 268, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 264, 'last_played': 1582500186}
review:
Un juego muy entretenido de aventuras roguelike que abre sus diversas mazmorras de forma procedural. 
Tienes 4 personajes a elegir y hasta donde se uno a desbloquear cuando acabas el juego.
SI bien el juego cumple muy bien su cometido cuando llevas unas horas jugando se puede volver soso y repetitivo. Muy pocos elementos, magias etc. Otra cosa que no me gusta es que no permite el modo ventana, porque es un pequeño juego que invita a jugar haciendo otras cosas en el pc. 
Su BSO es uno de los elementos en el que destaca pero en su conjunto se queda en una nota de 5/10
Existe una versión libre de un juego muy parecido a este, aunque la que merece la pena instalar es la de Android, que se llama shattered pixel dungeon, la podrás encontrar en Steam, pero no está actualizado.
Shattered, a diferencia de este si tiene muchos más elementos de magia, arma o consumo, también se puede explorar las mazmorras buscando pasajes ocultos etc... personalmente me parece más completo que este.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000695101', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 628, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 302, 'last_played': 1580364145}

author: {'steamid': '76561198066521419', 'num_games_owned': 3020, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 160, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 160, 'last_played': 1577987695}
review:
I finished the game in 2 hours, After I managed to defeat the first boss and work out a few tactics (with the shaman character), the rest of the game was pretty easy.

Graphics, music and controls are good. But the game really needed a bit deeper mechanics. There are no cursed items, identification, skill points, synergies, non-attack skills, equipment trade-offs, puzzles, environment mechanics... anything but the most basic walking and attacking. Every room is the same, every enemy is handled the same. Over and over again, until the end.

It's worth a few euros, but not more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055157769', 'num_games_owned': 418, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 829, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 770, 'last_played': 1576938904}
review:
Easy game even on hell mode, especially due to lack of variety in the playstyle-ennemies and game mechanics. 
Far from the best roguelikes, it's still enjoyable. But after 10 hours, it feel like I don't need to go further, and just return to Tales of Maj'Eyal which offers more depth and challenges.

author: {'steamid': '76561198211167295', 'num_games_owned': 407, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 131, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 108, 'last_played': 1594560073}
review: 이거 망겜임 이름에 잇는 쾌스트는 아무짝에도 별 필요 없고 이거하느니 차라리rogue 페이블인가 그거 하시죠 이거 개망맵노잼

author: {'steamid': '76561198268537934', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 242, 'playtime_forever': 785, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 785, 'last_played': 1568178269}
review:
The game is not bad, but it has some problems.

Pros:
+ Random generated dungeons.
+ Unique characters and their skills.
+ A lot of items and weapons.
+ Two kinds of side quests. You need to kill a boss or find something.
+ Sometimes you can find secret floor in a room.

Cons:
- Player is alone in the dungeon. You can't form a team in this game, and it doesn't support co-op mode.

- There is almost no limit to the location of random generated things. Once I found the merchant's room was behind the level boss. Another time the quest boss was generated in the same room of final boss.

- The most annoying thing is: Even if you have the best weapon and armors, some quest bosses still can kill you in one hit. Because no armor can protect you from a critical hit in the game. It will result a game over and forced you to start from beginning.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986013408', 'num_games_owned': 326, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 2759, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 672, 'last_played': 1710976767}
review: Quest of Dungeons is a rogue like game that I find I play more than just about any other game I own and I own a few! It's a game that randomly generates a dungeon. You mainly have a certain goal and that's to find the lantern of light to help save the kingdom from darkness. Sounds like an easy task? Don't be fooled. You could play a game and find yourself dead within the first few minutes or as just happened to me a few minutes ago.. Get down to the last battle and have my butt handed to me 'causing me to have to start over the game as it's permadeath in QOD! However, I found I just keep going back for more! It's fun.. hard at times and rewarding when you beat a level.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068360744', 'num_games_owned': 261, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 300, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 300, 'last_played': 1570133209}
review: Em poucas palavras, o jogo é estupidamente frustrante. Eu estava há 2 horas subindo de nível e simplesmente limpando as áreas de inimigos. Armadura incrível, arma poderosa, realmente poderoso. Até que me aparece uma múmia amarela que simplesmente me deu UM HIT KILL! QUE MERDA?! Não perca seu tempo nessa bosta, tem muito jogo por aí que vale MUITO mais a pena queimar 2 horas.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974484281', 'num_games_owned': 2306, 'num_reviews': 1398, 'playtime_forever': 464, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 464, 'last_played': 1561588161}

author: {'steamid': '76561198038364525', 'num_games_owned': 979, 'num_reviews': 120, 'playtime_forever': 1107, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 241, 'last_played': 1601336536}
review:
Sympathique rogue-like.Traduit en plusieurs langue dont le français,4 classes de personnages qui se jouent toutes différement.Une bonne re-jouabilité.Une difficulté bien dosée malgré le charactère aléatoire des maps.Fort amusant pour ceux qui aiment le genre et une bonne introduction pour ceux qui voudraient essayer le genre.Plusieurs niveaux de difficultés et une très bonne prise en main que ça soit à la manette ou au clavier/souris.Fort plaisant à jouer,parcourir les étages de ce donjon est très agréable.Les musiques sont assez vite énervantes mais on à la possibilité de les éteindre et d'y jouer sur les musiques de notre choix.Les sons sont vieillot mais colle bien à l'ambiance générale du jeu.Bestiaire évolutif avec les étages et si celui-ci est classique (rien vu d'innovant en 4 heures) on reconnait facilement chaque protagonistes constitués de pixels.Pas moche comme j'ai pus le lire.
De quoi passer un chouette moment à petit prix.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011595325', 'num_games_owned': 2476, 'num_reviews': 929, 'playtime_forever': 369, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 369, 'last_played': 1558326007}
review:
Quest of Dungeons promete ser um  roguelike, e se for é de longe o mais fácil que já joguei. Chega a ser tedioso, clicar nos inimigos, matar eles, pegar o loot, avançar pra próxima sala e repetir tudo, só tendo alguma variação em chefões. Não recomendo pelo fato de não ter nenhuma inovação e de existir outros jogos semelhantes a ele muito mais divertidos e com toques particulares.
--------------------------------
Quest of Dungeons promises to be a roguelike, and if it is it's by far the easiest I've ever played. It becomes tedious, click on enemies, kill them, get the loot, advance to the next room and repeat everything, only having some variation on bosses. I do not recommend it because it has no innovation and there are other games similar to it that are much more fun and with particular touches.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009861348', 'num_games_owned': 4630, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 1697, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 887, 'last_played': 1575195659}
review:
Personally, I'm quite fond of this dungeon crawling roguelite. It's overly simple, no crafting and best of all... fun, it draws you back in with its addictive little design and quick pickup and play. I feel it would've been better as a $2-3 game, but the price isn't too bad.

It may be a simplistic and use bought assets, but it delivers a nice little experience if you want a coffee break roguelite or something you can hop into, save and come back to later with minimal effort. Some of the spelling mistakes are kinda funny, while not being unintelligible or misinterpretable. It really is a tongue in cheek kinda game with enemies quipping off quotes from other games (or bosses stating they're humming the guile theme), which is nice.

At no point does this game take itself too seriously, and RNG WILL dictate your fate for most runs through. Quests (miniboss or fetch) add a little bit of extra legwork and a reason to revisit old areas sometimes but the real bane on progress is sometimes just the key availability. 3 doors and a chest all locked with light keys, every other key in your inventory but light keys and the stores on all 4 floors you've been to have no light keys to sell *facepalm*

author: {'steamid': '76561198366217823', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 2045, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 373, 'last_played': 1597197447}
review:
There is a major problem you should be aware of with this game. It is way too addicting.

There was a game I was obsessed with years back called Nethack, a game where I would get so dialed in with it, it felt almost like I was in a trance. You look up after playing for a little bit and realize that you've been playing for three hours. This is very similar to that game.

QoD is a rogue-like game (look up the original Rogue dos game to get an idea what started it all), much like Nethack and ADoM. Those games had extremely simplified graphics, no sounds, very little dialogue, but enough to get you into the spirit of adventure. A dungeon crawler. They were simple at the surface, but way more complex I realized the more I played. It was easy to fall down the rabbit hole.

QoD has that same spirit of adventure, but in a much more manageable (but no less addictive) way. The cute graphics, the nudges of humor, the little sounds, the music. I loved that there were tiny quests to do. One thing Nethack and ADoM lacked was the short-game payoff. The quests were long and it was rare to finish a quest before you died, but there are at least three or four quests on each floor of QoD. It makes it much more satisfying for the short game sessions.

There were a few differences that made the game a little more restricted and that I missed, such as clicking on the overview map to quickly get someplace, the ability to use an item on another item or throw it at an enemy (would have been nice to heal my minion). While the depth of the originals is a dangerous beast to approach, it does make it so rich--gaining a deity's favor, sacrificing corpses, identifying objects...

*ahem* anyway, yes. I recommend this game. Not only is it a fresh and modern take on an old classic, but the short game session appeal is unmistakeable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198263316031', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 462, 'playtime_forever': 189, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 189, 'last_played': 1551404936}
review:
Para ser un juego tan pequeño esta bien, no es una obra maestra pero funciona.
Es un rouge like bastante sencillo, tenemos 4 clases iniciales pero para mi el arquero es claramente la mejor.
Tiene varios pisos y cada piso tiene sus enemigos, y puedes encontrar incluso jefes.
Unas contra para mi son precisamente eso, los bosses si te los topas de frentes estas frito y un segundo detalle son lo controles que no estan bien explicados.
Esta bien para pasar un ratito.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065024955', 'num_games_owned': 1716, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 484, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 484, 'last_played': 1551342760}
review: Недо-рогалик, имбалансная фигня, тут у нас скелеты подвержены заклинанию страха, а лут не коррелируется с выбранным персом - махаешь посохом за шамана в ближнем бою, потому что тебе не выпадает хоть какое-то заклинание в дополнение к дефолтному.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065633156', 'num_games_owned': 134, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 318, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 318, 'last_played': 1544916339}
review:
Quest of Dungeons is fun at first. There are no complicated mechanics to be mastered or anything like that. It's just simple turn-based dungeon crawling with basic looting and leveling.

However, the game gets repetitive pretty quickly, and the character classes don't provide enough variation to the gameplay. 

Bosses can be extremely annoying with how stupidly overpowered they are. Their attacks crit frequently and even regular attacks can deal more damage than half of your total HP. Now imagine a boss that can use ranged attacks...

It doesn't really matter if you've been having a pretty good run with nice drops and enough XP to level up a couple of times. Bosses are almost always a chore to beat.

Bosses are the only (artificial) challenge in this game, the rest is trivial.

author: {'steamid': '76561198085754762', 'num_games_owned': 177, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1799, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1334, 'last_played': 1674877416}
review:
Since the most recent update, September 2018 (I'm pretty sure), I have a few things to say.

1. Game runs MUCH worse than it ever did, moving can cause incredible frame-rate issues that clear up sometimes for a minute, then go back. Makes everything very jagged and annoying.

2. This could just be coincidence, but in the last 3 playthroughs I've played, the number of quests and dungeons have lowered to 2 quests and 1 boss every 2 floors on average.

3. I never had this issue until now, which could just be my fault: in my last 3 playthroughs, I've been killed by accidently pressing a floortile instead of the ability. It's incredibly frustrating to know, 'oh, I died because I mis-clicked'. And yes, in the settings I have 'Stop moving when hit', yet they don't even when hit. So unless the setting is just poorly-named and does something else - it doesn't work.

I love this game, and I've been wanting to get more achievements for it; it's been impossible though, thanks to mistake alone that has got me killed. Some of these issues I believe have been around since when I last played, before the recent update - doesn't change a thing though, really.

I still recommend the game, but please, do something about these issues, and any others I've forgotten/missed.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979581744', 'num_games_owned': 2039, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 276, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 230, 'last_played': 1576538725}
review: Bought this game because I was happy to see that they'd ported it over from android and I've spent countless hours on this game on my phone when on the toilet or bored at work. It's simple, fun and you can quit at any point and continue exactly where you left off. I'd recommend this game for anyone looking for a nice little light hearted dungeon crawler without a super indepth stat/class system.

author: {'steamid': '76561198121243641', 'num_games_owned': 2405, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 82, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 82, 'last_played': 1536091538}
review:
It's not bad, really it's not... it's just... cheap? Limited classes, limited character development, no visible equipment, simple combat, etc. On the positive side, each level of the dungeon is BIG, and the mini-map is super useful. Also, the quest, key, secret stash, and boss mechanics all add a bit of flair to the otherwise familiar gameplay.

Overall, about what you would expect given the price, to be fair. But then again you can buy Tales of Maj'Eyal for only $2 more so... meh? This is really not on the level  of ToME, it's more along the lines of Pixel Dungeon or Cardinal Quest 2 (which are both excellent mobile roguelikes, don't get me wrong).

Controls are simple to use and well suited to touchscreen play, so if you want to try this I recommend you pick it up cheaper on a mobile platform instead. $2 on Android or iOS...

Enjoy!

author: {'steamid': '76561198104060693', 'num_games_owned': 1808, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 521, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 269, 'last_played': 1709333755}

Só há pouco tempo percebi, que o mix perfeito e que me faz pregar olho a cada vez que jogo, é sem dúvida o look e feel de boardgame (ou D&D) que se une de forma perfeita a um RPG minimalista! author: {'steamid': '76561197966074683', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 73, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 66, 'last_played': 1539396922}
review: Being the 90's kid that grew up on EGA graphics and had to always catch up to new games due to cost, the graphics don't seem as important as the value/content I get for my purchase. This game is really worth the cash just on replay value. Simple design, great story, easy casual while suspenseful gameplay that keeps you on your toes.  Looks like  a project of love and a meld of nethack, gauntlet, with a pinch of gate of doom. Love the whitty humor there used to be in old school games, this has it in bulk. It has been such a treat on the Switch, I just had get it on the PC. I think once you given the game a few weeks you will eventally walk away from it. But once you notice it in your library you will want to play for a few more weeks. On a trip this would help with the airport or hotel room blues. I really can't wait to see what these developer come up with next. Gives me that happy feeling of what PC gaming used to be.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981862238', 'num_games_owned': 773, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 191, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 84, 'last_played': 1690513114}
review:
Fun game with many cheap deaths.
You'll invest a lot of time into your run for it all to be completely pointless.

author: {'steamid': '76561198109604941', 'num_games_owned': 236, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 152, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 152, 'last_played': 1539906630}
review:
[h1] 11 / 10 Skill Books [/h1]
[i]TL;DR version: Just buy it! You WON'T regret it (IMO), I know I didn't and my potato PC loves it![/i]

Having bought almost all the platform versions (3DS/2DS, android & PC) of this game, I've probably accumulated a total of 100+hrs of gameplay time. If you like rogue-like TD dungeon crawlers, at least check it out, definitely worth every penny (IMO). But, that's not the game's only focus. It has a strong focus on inventory management (deciding what to keep to sell and use and what to leave behind), procedurally generated (randomly generated) dungeons, unlockable classes, unlockable stories/crawls, beautiful nostalgic pixel art, good and dark humour, strategy and it even presents a customised experience so you can choose how hard, big, deep/tall you want your crawl to be! I personally love this title and have it in my featured games tab on my profile and aim to get all the Steam Badges and achievements for it and beyond! With the developer being so active, it gets regular updates, bug fixes, hotfixes and new features. Plus, it's replayability is immense! Of all the playthroughs I've done, not a single one has been like an other. I say just give it a try! If my potato can play it, so can yours! ^~^

ADDITIONAL NOTE: The developer of this game is VERY interactive w/ us players on multiple forums and social media fronts (i.e. Twitter, Facebook, Reddit), providing him w/ bug reports and suggestions that constantly help him update and upgrade/hotfix the game.

[EDIT:]This edit was added for David Amador, creator of QoD; Currently having review listing issues, seeing if editing and updating my review will cause it to show up, everything above this edit, still stands true, IMHO

review:
For the couple of dollars it costs, it's worth the 5+ hours you'll get out of your first couple playthroughs.

Pros:
Feels smooth when advancing through levels
Quests spice things up
Will run on a potato

Cons:
Very repetitive
No visual changes when putting on different armor or weapons
Limited storyline
Lazy character and level design

review: An enjoyable, though sometimes unforgiving, take on a dungeon crawler.  One of the mechanics of the game is permadeath so it is often wise to shut the door double back if you accidentally run across a boss early on a level.  The various character classes, random dungeon generation, and random item drops keeps the game fresh with subsequent playthroughs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020198866', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 2110, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1977, 'last_played': 1654112441}
review:
J'ai vu des commentaire avec des "oh c'est chiant faut cliquer partout" ou "oh mais les graphismes ils sont mal fait"... clairement c'est le but non? 
Plus concrètement, c'est un jeu de donjon/fantaisie qui me plaît beaucoup :
-Les personnages qui ont vraiment des caractéristiques très variés et qui offrent un gameplay complètement différent tout en restant facil à prendre en main.
-Le tour par tour est bien réalisé mais un peu traitre quand on passe en spped run.
-Les effets de vision du personnage sont bien pensés, on voit pas l'autre bout du donjon si on a un mur devant nous!

Bref on a tout ce qu'il faut : un donjon, des boss et de la baston

Mais au bout d'un moment c'est assez répétitif, on arrive très loin dans le donjon une fausse manip (ça pardonne pas) et bim one shot tu recommences à zéro.

Au final les seules choses que je repprooche vraiment à ce jeu c'est que sur les versions smartphone et Nintendo 3ds on peut pas passer de tour (touche "Entrer" sur PC) et ça complique beaucoup quelques techniques que j'ai réussi à utiliser sur pc. Peut être bientôt des mises à jour qui sait! En attendant si vous hésitez encore, pour le prix d'un kebab vous avez un super jeu.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054595842', 'num_games_owned': 82, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1612, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 870, 'last_played': 1548213274}
review:
Quest of Dungeon originally got my attention simply for the funny trailer, however as I sank a few hours in, I felt like it was the devs that got the last laugh. This is not worth your money at all. And here's why in this long list of issues.

-The game is overly simple. The game throws at you ton food items that any experienced Roguelike player would expect them to serve a greater purpose aka hunger. Here, their only purpose is simply to (restore a bit of HP). They are basically just lesser Health Potion. Also, The only strategy involved with any character is to spam skills whenever they are available. There's no wands of teleport or rings of polymorph to be found here. No fun silly deaths that you'd find in other roguelike eitheir. Here. [i] Your deaths will be solely attributed to dying to a boss you shouldn't have tackled yet.[/i] (But you had no way of knowing prior).

- One design choice of other turn based Roguelike is to walk or pass a turn to restore HP, usually you can fast foward this to make this take second and you can't do it forever or you will starve. In this game however. It becomes a gigantic issue that ruins replayability. 

As the Warrior. You gain a very small chunk of HP by walking 5-6 steps. It takes about 2 minutes of walking back and forth aimlessly in a room to be fighting fit again. THIS IS THE OPTIMAL WAY OF PLAYING. THE GAME ENCOURAGES YOU TO DO SO SINCE THERE'S NO HUNGER SYSTEM. So if you're playing on Hard difficulty. You'ill want to save as many health potion as possible for later. So after every encounters. You should be ready to do the tedious task of regenerating HPs. By walking in a circle around the room. Also, enemies that doesn't appears within your view range just doesn't move at all. So you'ill never be taken by suprise by doing this tedious task. By the way, The Mage character only restore MP while walking around, not both. Enjoy the tedious task of spinning right 'round the rooms for MP instead of HP. 

[b]Now I want you to picture this: You open a door, a boss appears a few square away. You use any skills available to prepare for the encounter such as Defense Skill and the Warrior's Shout Skill that can stun an enemy for a long time. You manage to stun the boss, you go in for the kill, inexplicably miss thrice. Then the boss acts, he gets a critical hit. You took half you HP bar on that one crit. You get out of the boss room into the other square shaped room you came from, then walk in a circular motion around the room as the boss tails you the entire time without any way of actually hitting you, since nothing will ever come and block your path. You keep turning around the room for a solid 2 minute to replenish all your HP. Then go in for a hit, you hit the boss a few times and so does he, your HP are at critical. Which only means... More of the silly cat and mouse chase around the room until your HP bar is full again[/b]

-Quest of Dungeon encourages grinding, as much as possible to progress. The anwers to everything is just to have a stronger character instead of having more knowledge then a less experienced player. The only thing to learn are the way to cheese the skills you learn trough randomly dropped books. Basically. All the Warrior's skills has a cooldown after use. (He doesn't have MP to worry about) Let's say your Bleeding Hit skill failed on the boss, You now have a 50+ turn cooldown before you can use it again. You know what that means? You're gonna be running around in circle around the room some more until the skill is available again! Superb! 10/10 gameplay right here. Also on a lesser note, trough the dungeons are stones that activates quest. But there's only 2 variety of quest. Quest A: Kill that boss. Quest B: Find an item that just randomly spawned around the dungeon. Both serves the only purpose of making you revisit the entire floor again with a vague hint of (The item or boss is situated north). You HAVE to do these quest if you want to survive on Normal or above. Pretty lackluster for a game called Quest of Dungeons.

Now on to the smaller stuff...

-Unlimited skill slot, at no point you will have to make a choice of having a healing spell above stun effect spell. The only anwers is just to read all the spell book you can find until all further books you find becomes (Book of Nothing) which you can sell to the merchant for a quick buck.

-Pointless traps that are always in plain sight. In other Roguelike, traps would be invisible to the player until they stepped on it, or had a method of finding them. Here, you will want to step on the spawn monster trap. So you can grind more XP.
Also the game features props like a shelves, pots, boxes and other thing that can be destroyed or search for gold or items. And sometime breaking a pot will inexplicabably trigger a trap that makes enemies spawns from the ceiling. (I guess these skeletons were really pissed I just broke their favorite pot?) One last thing about special tiles. There are invisible stash that can be walked on that yeild more gold, but those are stumbled only trough pure luck, or walking on every tiles of a dungeon. But you'd have to be crazy to do that.

-Equipement makes no friggin' sence. Very rarely weapons has additional attributes like (More gold) or (2+ Crits). There's a multitude of weapon sprite, however, that sweet crystal shield you just found could be beaten by that random wood buckler you had laying around in your inventory stats wise. Don't get me started on the equipement name etheir. In the same playtrough, I've got two exact looking pair of boots. One was named (The Boots) with 12 point of DEF, the other pair was named: (Damaged Boots) with 16 points of DEF. 

This is explained by the fact that all piece of equipment you find seems to have random generated names, it slaps random adjective to the item, so you'ill get things like (Dark Sigil Sword Seeker). Way to confuse new players to think there's actually depth to be found here.


-Enemies with ranged capacities are the bane of your existence. And if it's a boss with spells or a bow. Run, and pray that you don't get immolated by that fireball or get a random crit from that arrow. You can ultimately trick them to follow you around the room like other melee bosses, but first you got to walk up to them, and by then you're already on the brink of death.

-Item menu, as far as I know, cannot be used with arrow keys or keyboard imput, you have to use your mouse. Same goes for choosing a skill. It would have been nice to be able set the skills to the F1-F6 keys instead of clicking the spell book every time you want to switch.

-Along gold, you'ill find gems along the way, there's at least 8 or so sort of gems that are worth maybe 15 to then 20 GP each. Each kind of gem stack with each other, but if you find 6 sort of gems in a row and you're short on inventory space, you'd rather just leave that gem there and avoid the clutter, because ultimately, finding just one random piece of equipement will make those gems feel like chum changes when you realise that even the worst shield can be worth 1000+ GP. 

-Enemies sometime spout some random lines like: (The cake is a lie) or (You should have taken the blue pill) or even worst (I am your father). Too bad that the humor stops the moment you step in the dungeon. Because the trailer and intro was really funny in comparaison.

-Your sprite will never change to reflect the equipement you've equipped and that's really unfortunate and lazy. 

- Last and more important. It's a roguelike where you have to grind and it's never fun to die.


Ultimately, I can't recommend this game to veteran or neophytes alike. At best this game is a good distraction while watching something on the side or eating... 

If roguelikes are something you might be interested in, go for a free Roguelike like POWDER which is made by one guy and is much more deep. Or you know, dish more money for a roguelike worth it's salt like FTL or Darkest Dungeon.

author: {'steamid': '76561198242083536', 'num_games_owned': 54, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 243, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 64, 'last_played': 1505482055}
review:
This game is a rogue-like dungeon-crawler.

Firstly, you have to choose between four different classes (Warrior, Wizard, Assassin, Shaman) and four difficulties (Easy, Normal, Hard, Hell).

Then the game starts, and you have to go through 7 floors killing monsters in order to get xp, money and items.

You will encounter bosses that are quite challenging to kill. Do not hesitate to escape, by closing the door that you opened a few seconds ago for instance, if you think that you will have a hard time killing a scary boss !

You will trigger quests (between 0-3 at each floor) that require to either kill a boss or find an item. You'll be rewarded with both money and xp. I think that you should clean an entire floor before triggering a quest (at least in Hard /Hell difficulties). The point I want to make is that if this is a boss quest, you might be in trouble if you have to fight a boss that you've just spawned plus some regular monsters.

Cleaning an entire floor will bring you everything you need : xp, money and items. You should get the best stuff you can and some potions before fighting the final boss. Regarding this final boss, I do not want to spoil people, but there is one thing I want to say : how is it possible to give him the ability to kill us with one skill and one shot ? If the skill "Death" hits you, you will die 10 turns later, no matter what you do ... You have to hope that it will fail :s

Regarding the achievements, there are quite easy to unlock, except maybe for the one that needs you to beat the game in Hell mode.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055977195', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 198, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 198, 'last_played': 1484710289}
review:
Quest of Dungeons
About The Game: Quest of Dungeons is a turn-based, rouge-like, RPG. The object of the game is simple, DON'T DIE!. Navigate the dungeons killing monsters, gaining exp, and collecting loot. You can switch out your equipment but leveling up just gives strait stat boosts. Skills come in the form of tomes you find. Some skills work better for some classes than others. The dungeons are randomly generated and can have multiple stairways. Some of the doors take keys to open them and there is no garantee that you will find that key on that floor. Backtracking to open a door on a previous floor might not be worth it since loot matches the floor you are on and not your level.

Pantsu's Rating (out of 5)
Graphics: 2.5 Nothing special here. 8 bit characters and monsters. The map shows what keys you need to get through the locked door but sometimes they are hard to see.
Playability: 3 With WSDA movement and some changeable hotkeys you are never confused on what to do.
Fun: 2 Perhaps it is because I chose the archer for my first run, but after the challenge of the first boss I didn't have much problems. I only died because I gave up caring. The game also trolls you right at the start with a sign showing a skull. I clicked on it looking for lore, instead found instant death.
Sound: 3.5 Even though the game is in old school graphics they actually tried with the background music. Different tunes play when you enter certain rooms and floors.
Replay Value: 3 There are 4 classes to play so there is some replay by challenging yourself on how far you can get with each class. Plus randomised maps and loot make each attempt a little different.
Final Score: 2.75 
Final Thought: At $4.99 definitely wait for a sale. I believe I got this game for 49 cents.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972470541', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 2473, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2446, 'last_played': 1483890146}
review: complete waste of time and money.  Unless you like a game where you spend hours just moving forward and the developer then throws in an enemy that arbitrarily one-hits you, or a goblin robs you of 500+ gold when it took more than one level to even EARN that much.  Where having food or potions is meaningless because taking one just postpones the next death from blows doing more damage than is healed, and more than half of your own attacks are just dodged.  Not to mention portals that take you ALL the way to the other side of the same room.  The game is not fun, just petty.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041337530', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 5898, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5572, 'last_played': 1544290001}
review:
Lets face it. This is a pre-teen roguelike rpg game, a great introduction into genre. Simple mechanics  and plenty of stuff to collect, kids love it. For more experianced its undemanding mind-off resting game from heavier titles. 
As said, this is good place to start your journey into dungeon crawlers, rpg and roguealikes.

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198022387235', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 127, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 127, 'last_played': 1483389107}
review:
An extremely repetitive game with almost nothing to unlock.

In this game, you choose a character, you choose dungeon, and you progress between floors by killing enemies, looting stuff, finding keys, opening chests, killing bosses and finding stairs. (Be sure to read this list well. It's all you'll do in this game.)
There are two dungeons in total plus a custom dungeon mode. No story at all, almost no text or cutscenes.
Each floor works exactly like the last. Only the colors and the enemies change slightly.
Also, all enemies are basically the same. Some have a ranged attack or a special ability, but most of the time it doesn't change anything.
Bosses really are stronger than other monsters but they're still not interesting at all.
There are five playable characters in total.
They can gain new abilities during the course of the game. One 2 hours game where I explored everything was more than enough for me to unlock ALL my character's abilities.
Also, most of these abilities are pretty useless. Your first ability will always be the main one. Most abilities aren't even subtle or interesting; it's mainly just "deals more damage in a larger zone but costs more mana and has a longer cooldown". There's almost no strategy at all in this game.

Some games have a bad repetitive gameplay but are still fun. That's because in these games you can unlock things, which is a nice perspective for players who like to collect things or access to new ways to play. Others have a nice story or atmosphere and make you dream. But this game doesn't have any of that. It is both boring and pointless, and its gameplay is almost inexistant.
Your first game will be nice. But as as soon as you finish it and read the achievements, you'll understand that you have nothing more to do here.

Don't buy this unless you can have it for $1 and you have a lot of time to loose.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000063187', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 334, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 211, 'last_played': 1601291670}
review:
В целом не так плохо, понравился юмор, но как-то проходится без напряга. Я ожидал килотонну смертей от голода, ловушек, монстров и т.д. но в итоге еда нужна только для восстановления здоровья, ловушки наносят по 15 урона, монстры не представляют угрозы, даже если соберутся толпой.

Если вы играли в Pixel Dungeon, то это игра покажется вам ОЧЕНЬ легкой.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972625158', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 18, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1482724959}
review:
This is a great introduction to "real" rogue-likes for anyone interested in giving DCSS, et al. a try but too afraid to jump into the deep-end.

It simplifies (or removes) many mechanics, which makes it much more approachable for players new to the genre.

If you have never played DCSS, I recommend this game whole-heartedly. If you are a veteran DCSS player,  you will end up posting a review about the developer being a "poor designer".

Bonus points for having full controller support. Loses points for having "music" so repetitive I wanted to turn it off in less than 5 minutes of playing the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995436761', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 388, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 378, 'last_played': 1482631987}
review:
A lot of the negative reviews focus on the fact that Quest of Dungeouns - hereafter known as QD - lacks the same depth as other games in the genre. I think it's important to bear in mind that QD wasn't meant to be complex and "deep." It's a simple dungeon crawler that you can choose to play for ten minutes then put it down and come back another time. The game has a nice sense of humor about it, the music is nice but it could have used a few more tunes. 

Don't go in expecting QD to ADOM or Moria, if you do you will be disappointed. Rather approach it as a way to just play to relax and you'll find that the "one more dungeoun level" feeling will be yours.

It's five bucks folks and it provides much more fun than the sticker price would have you believe.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005741042', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 107, 'playtime_forever': 440, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 325, 'last_played': 1553290873}
review:
Que vois-je à l'horizon ? Le Q de Robin.. euh non je vois le Q de Quest of Dungeon. Avec un grand ou un petit Q ? Hé bien, cela dépend de l'angle d'approche en fait. Pour les joueurs qui ont pu être alléchés par le produit sur Greenlight et qui l'ont supporté jusqu'à sa publication, c'est un grand Q. Pour les autres, qui ne connaissent rien de ce jeu et qui découvrent ce test, cela restera le petit Q de la question : Que vaut-il ? Car en effet avec le nombre de roguelikes sortis ces derniers mois, il n'est pas du tout évident qu'il trouve sa place pour poser son Q au soleil. Explications.  

La suite de ce test : http://rpgjeuxvideo.eklablog.fr/quest-of-dungeons-a127287716

review: If you can tell from how many hours I clocked in on this game, I love it! It's hard enough to be nearly frustrating but fun enough that every time I die I think 'okay, this time I'll get that achievement!' and since it is a rogue-type game replaying it is always a new adventure! The graphics and 2D top-down is charming and the simple controls take no time to get used to. All in all, one of my favorite games!
